title: Wednesday, 18th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Hi there

PM11:01am

Who'd have thought the day would arrive when I'd post this at the top of a Markets Live session here at FTAV...

PM11:01am

11:01 am
PM11:01am

John Fallen, will be former ceo of Pearson, I suspect

PM11:01am

Who saw this coming?

PM11:01am

Oh, we did

11:01 am
BE11:02am

Be fair. Everyone did.

BE11:02am

Except Mr Fallon.

PM11:02am

Some more than others Bryce

11:02 am
PM11:02am

I feel one or two analysts need a shout out here

PM11:02am

This chap, for one

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Ian Whittaker of Liberum

BE11:03am

Smart chap. I was once on a pub quiz with him. (We won, no thanks to me.)

PM11:03am

This time a year ago, just as Pearson was rallying hard (and i was throwing the towel in in the face of a 6.5% dividend pledge)...

11:03 am
PM11:04am

Whittaker cut his TP from 540p to 450p

PM11:04am

The stock was trading at 758p at the time

PM11:04am

And he stuck with it

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Here's his summary from that day

PM11:04am

Pearson’s shares reacted strongly to its trading update
statement last week, where it announced a profit warning
for FY16E and an even more extensive restructuring
programme than back in 2013. It also promised to maintain
its dividend. This appears a classic case of a company’s
long-term prospects being sacrificed for short-term
dividend support, which in any event may be unsustainable
unless the company makes further asset sales (with its
stake in Penguin Random House the most obvious). We cut
FY16E estimates by 16% and reduce the target price from
540p to 450p. Reiterate as Key Sell.

PM11:04am

One more shout out...

11:04 am
PM11:04am

PM11:04am

Neil Campling of Northern Trust

PM11:05am

That was clearly an early morning appearance for Neil on CNBC

11:05 am
PM11:05am

But to today's news

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 583.00, down 225 (-27.85%), High: 659.50, Low: 583.00, Volume: 13.26m
PM11:05am

wow

11:05 am
BE11:05am

So, to put this in a longer-term context ......

BE11:06am

Market cap graph, rather than share price. Annotated by me with regards key events in Pearson's recent past.

BE11:06am

11:06 am
PM11:06am

The one thing Pearson has been good at over the years is selling businesses

PM11:06am

Thank goodness they sold us

PM11:07am

Otherwise we'd be in PR right about now

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Random Penguin was the distraction in today's profit warning, of course. Many news organisations led up their first take with that rather than the guidance cut.

PM11:07am

(Boncoeur -- maybe, he just looked a bit ruffled)

BE11:07am

Let me rewind though.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

sure

BE11:08am

Guidance goes to £570m-£630m of EBITA for 2017, EPS of 48.5p-
55.5p based on end December 2016 exchange rates.

PM11:08am

And the dividend?

11:08 am
BE11:09am

EPS consensus was 64p, by the way, so it's a mahoosive downgrade.

PM11:09am

Pick up a Penguin payout, maybe...

BE11:09am

........ Raising all sorts of questions about why management didn't guide down sooner. (I'm ignoring that pun out of politeness).

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Here's Goldman's summary.

BE11:10am

Key takeaways: (1) Pearson has rebased guidance for 2017 to adjusted operating profit of £570-630m (GSe/company-compiled cons: £720m) and adjusted EPS of 48.5-55.5p (GSe/cons: 64.14p/63.5p). This mainly reflects the company’s expectations of the US college business continuing to decline in 2017 vs previous expectations of a stabilisation.
(2) Pearson has removed its guidance for 2018 and announced that it intends to sell its 47% stake in PRH (or recapitalise the business and extract
a dividend).
(3) The company has reiterated operating profit guidance for 2016 and now expects to report full-year organic growth of -8%, lower than our estimate of -6.4%, due to further declines in North America higher education courseware (30% decline in 4Q). It expects 2016 adjusted operating profit of £630m (GSe £615m) and adjusted EPS of c.57p (GSe 54p), driven mainly by higher-than-expected discretionary cost savings, but the company noted that the base level of underlying profitability for 2017 is around £180m lower than it expected in early 2016.
(4) Beyond this, the company plans to accelerate investment in its technology platforms, investing £50m and getting involved in the courseware rental market through reducing ebook prices and launching a print rental program.

PM11:10am

Everyone else in the US sector warned.... why not Fallon

11:10 am
BE11:10am

That's the key question, really.

PM11:11am

The answer I guess is that he wanted to arrange the Penguin sale first

BE11:11am

That's .... well, maybe. By their figures, Q4 was disastrous. North America Higher Education Courseware down 30%.

11:11 am
PM11:12am

ouch

BE11:12am

Barclays ............

BE11:12am

This is a major capitulation in terms of management’s plans for the business, after a Q3 trading update when they were sticking to their story on how the shape of textbook returns would mean that 2017 would be better. It is very difficult to find positives here and we believe that the investment community will need to hear exactly what the new story is once numbers have been rebased. Certainly nothing in the statement suggests that value hunters should be investigating the investment case on a multi-year view

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Ive got Campling's post-call notes

PM11:12am

Five issues arriving from the call for us. 1. The dividend issue. It is clear that they can't commit as they will likely need the Penguin Random House disposal to prop up the balance sheet 2. Margin issue. Guidance may mask that new restructuring is likely needed. Profit risks seem high. Expect a plethora of downgrades to follow. 3. Lack of visibility. Which suggests 2017 guidance could actually prove too optimistic given the company admit to getting two key issues wrong in 2016. 4. Is company masking a shift to free materials? We were unconvinced by management's view that free and rental shifts could benefit Pearson market share over time (especially when disruptor Amazon is in the market). 5. Management Credibility.

There are "too many moving parts" for Pearson to commit to the base dividend. Assuming a base of 2x cover then a dividend of approximately 25p in 2017 would suggest c.4.2% DY post the 26% stock price decline today. The stock would have to fall to closer to £4 to get back to the same F12M dividend yield the stock was trading at yesterday. We see no reason to cover the shorts here.

PM11:12am

hehe

11:12 am
PM11:13am

Think if you do see a deadcat here tomorrow or later in the week, Sell it

BE11:13am

Liberum too, since you flagged them up as shrewd.

BE11:13am

(Correctly.)

11:13 am
BE11:14am

We would take the following key points away from the call:

Pearson's end game here seems to move to something like the increasingly successful music streaming market i.e. you get consumers (students) to subscribe and pay you a regular fee for your product. One of the core problems is that much of Pearson's content, at the end of the day, is not proprietary e.g. the principles of calculus have been known for centuries, and so it can be replicated in one form or another. Pearson's previous strength was derived from control of the distribution network and this is now breaking down.
Rentals will continue to impact the market and also impact visibility on the inventory levels. Management stated that part of the reason for the -12% inventory impact on US Higher Education sales in 2018E was due to changes in incentivising staff on a net sales basis (I.e adjusted for returns), not gross sales. The concern has to be that not only do rentals continue to grow but there is an acceleration effect and that its impact grows more and more each year. We do not think Pearson’s plans will offset this effect.
Piracy might be becoming an issue in the US Higher Education business. Pearson admitted that one of the reasons for looking to move to a more subscription based model is to reduce the threat from piracy and also suggested the industry will take more measures to tackle piracy. Reading between the lines, this suggests that the problem is growing and is becoming of concern. We have been focused on the impact of rentals but this might be another area to track, as well as Open Education Resources, which Pearson said is a small but growing share of the market.
The dividend is likely to be cut substantially. Pearson management stated that there needed to be greater coverage of the dividend moving forwards. If we assumed a mid-point of 2017E EPS guidance (48.5p-55.5p) at 52p and assumed 2x coverage that implies a 26p dividend, half of the previous 52p guidance level. However, it could be lower because that guidance includes Penguin Random House, which might be sold, so the dividend could be lower.
Penguin Random House sale could lead to significant dilution. Depending on what Pearson does with its 47% stake in PRH (sell it or recapitalising it up to 3.5x net debt /. EBITDA, with the latter’s 100% EBITDA at $500m), a sale could mean at least mid-teens adjusted EPS dilution. Pearson has to think about how it wants to manage the balance between this, dividend support and debt reduction.
2017E guidance includes a likely benefit from a more than average set of new editions into the US Higher Education market. In 2014 (which was really the only year since 2012 where consensus expectations were not lowered from initial expectations), we think Pearson benefited significantly from the roll-out of new editions into the US Higher Education market (its print revenues look to have declined low single digits in that year). Given the three-year cycle nature of the business, management admitted that 2017 will see another spike in new editions and that is included in guidance, which suggests that 2018 will see a drag effect as the number of new editions drops off.

BE11:14am

Management are finally admitting that the problems are structural after several years but it is too little, too late. 50% of its US Higher Education revenues (and probably a larger % of profits) are still print and that means that Pearson still has much of its business at risk, particularly as there are few reasons why students would want to buy textbooks in the $150-200 range when there are increasingly cheaper options.

BE11:15am

Sellers since 2011. But when you're right, you're right ......

11:15 am
PM11:15am

How about Exane? Did they have it as a pick of the year (last year)?

PM11:15am

I may be wrong on that

BE11:15am

Haven't seen. There were several buyers around though, by memory.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Hmm

PM11:16am

Before we move on, I have to report something suspicious

?

Though not enough profit warnings.

Premier Foods PLC (PFD:LSE): Last: 40.60, down 7.4 (-15.42%), High: 42.00, Low: 40.25, Volume: 8.63m

Tough game, cakes.

Not so Premier Q3 here http://www.investe...1701180700104109U/

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Yep, it's all the issue of passing on higher costs to supermarkets. Pound pushes up sugar, wheat and etc.

BE11:22am

Supermarkets don't want to wear the LFL hit, and they're rather bigger than their suppliers.

BE11:22am

So, Premier to miss expectations by 10%.

11:22 am
PM11:23am

(OJatHome -- theyve always secured good prices. Quality of what they were selling another matter...)

BE11:23am

There's also the winding down of the "buy three, throw two away" offers that started more than a year ago, but Premier only now seems to have noticed.

BE11:23am

Grocery categories have been affected by changing retailer
promotional strategies, notably a reduction in multi-buy
promotions.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

You'll also remember Gavin Darby, Premier's CEO, rejecting 65p a share from McCormick in April.

PM11:24am

Oh yes!

BE11:25am

There was quite a bit of Jedi mind stuff from Premier's Feltcollaredsource around that rejection, which I'm not sure has been played out by history.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Credit Suisse incoming. Charlie Mills, of course.

BE11:26am

■ A very disappointing Q3 and outlook statement sees Premier Foods warn that profits are set to be 10% below consensus. We lower our estimates accordingly and price target to 43p
■ Q3 sales were down 1% rather than the modest increase that had been expected post H1, with Q3 volumes up 3.4% but price/mix -4.4%. No full year sales guidance is now offered (at H1 the group was expecting +2-4% in H2) , but the group expects the immediate trading backdrop to remain challenging.
■ The group highlights in Grocery a shift in promotional trends in the trade away from multi-packs putting corresponding pressure on volumes - to offset this price promotions were put in place but this has had a marked impact on profits. In Cakes Kipling has lost ground to own label. In general, market shares haven't fallen, the group sees this as market not market share driven

BE11:27am

All this is taking place against a backdrop of significant input cost pressure which is beginning to feed into the P&L. The group is mitigating where it can but along with many in the UK is seeking price increases (of mid single digits we assume). In the current climate some lag in gaining these increases is inevitable.
■ Expected year end debt of £525m is not much different to the £521m we had. The group has identified a further £10m of cost savings for 2017/18 and the same again in the new year, largely it seems from merging the supply chains of the two divisions.
■ It is very disappointing to report this continued decline in sales despite all the efforts of the company. £10m cost savings in each of the next 2 years may help protect profits to some degree, but is set against the on-coming input cost inflation. The investment case needs sales growth and that continues to prove elusive.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

This line from the statement struck me as very stark:

PM11:27am

The Group is experiencing material input cost inflation, notably in commodities such as sugar, chocolate, dairy, wheat and palm oil. Input costs have also been driven up by currency devaluation.

PM11:28am

This must be affecting a serious part of the London market

11:27 am
PM11:28am

It's very real

PM11:28am

You just need to talk to a grocer

BE11:28am

......... Yes, sure. Though there's another dimension here.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Companies with extremely strong brands are better at passing on costs than companies with not so strong brands.

BE11:29am

We've seen Mr Kipling lose ground to own label, as per the statement.

BE11:30am

Guessing similar things happen with Homepride, Sharwood's, Oxo, Bisto .... All of which have decent shelf recognition but are not, let's face it, unfungible.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

Interesting

BE11:30am

(Is "unfungible" a word? It is now.)

BE11:30am

Quick bit of Shore.

11:00 am
PM11:00am

Welcome to ML

BE11:32am

Incidentally, it seems my deep-dive into the noodle market has also been washed from the FT archive.

PM11:32am

11:32 am
BE11:32am

BE11:32am

Oh no, wait, here it is: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2016-04-26/

undefined
11:32 am
BE11:33am

And sticking with profit warnings, Mitie.

PM11:33am

http://www.investe...1701180700124397U/

PM11:33am

The FD's also off -- Suzanne Baxter

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Yep. This is after the Sunday Times had a story in on .... Sunday .... about Mitie's accounts and its new CEO taking a tougher line on revenue recognition.

BE11:34am

All to do with IFRS 15, which is likely to require all sorts of companies to revise historic profits.

BE11:35am

Anyway, that's to come later. For now, we get a third profit warning from Mitie in four months.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

underlying EBITA for 2017 to be in the range of £60m to 70m.

BE11:35am

Peel Hunt to summarise what that means vs expectations.

BE11:36am

Property Management and Technical FM have been impacted
by client deferrals and investment plan delays, respectively, which are now expected to fulfilled in 2Q 2017. Separately, Cleaning is underperforming; management changes are being implemented. As a consequence, MITIE now expect underlying EBITA for FY2017 to be in the range of £60m to 70m (including ongoing healthcare losses, but before the previously disclosed £10m one-off costs of change).

11:36 am
BE11:36am

In addition, the Board is undertaking a balance sheet
review and has taken a more conservative judgement on contractual positions, identifying an additional £14m of one-off charges in the year. The balance sheet review will also consider the potential impact of IFRS 15 (Revenue recognition).

BE11:36am

PHe FY2017E PBT of £74.4m (EPS 16.5p) is based upon £90.1m of EBITA, so the revised guidance implies a downgrade of £20m to £30m (27-40%) to £44.4m to £54.4m and EPS of 9.7p-to 11.9p (downgrade comprises £14m of one-offs and£6m to £16m relates to trading). Despite the lower forecasts, management expect to continue operating within banking covenants (net debt/EBITDA less than 3.0x)

PM11:37am

So Bryce, do you have further thoughts on IFRS 15?

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Omg smile

BE11:38am

Well, not particularly, as I'm not an accountant.

PM11:38am

Comes in Jan next year

11:38 am
BE11:38am

But the confusion over Rolls' guidance at the back end of last year does rather suggest it's an elephant in the room for any number of companies.

PM11:39am

There's a concise explanation at wikipedia

PM11:39am

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IFRS_15

11:38 am
PM11:39am

But im not an accountant either

BE11:39am

Rolls, clearly, is exposed due to the way it pre-books revenue for service contracts rather than wearing the entire loss of selling a very expensive jet engine for nearly nothing.

BE11:40am

But this is pretty much how a lot of software companies work as well, on a smaller scale, and I've not seen any updates from them.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

hmm...

undefined
BE11:40am

Inmarsat mentioned earlier.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

No2 on the 250 fallers board

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 670.00, down 35 (-4.96%), High: 700.50, Low: 659.50, Volume: 2.39m
BE11:40am

Caz this time.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Actually, there's a slew of research out on Inmarsat this morning, mostly saying "short term headwinds" ........

BE11:42am

... Caz is the one that downgrades though. Here it is.

BE11:42am

The Inmarsat buy case is predicated on the belief GX will unlock new revenue opportunities, and underpin a double digit EBITDA growth outlook. Whilst we remain confident in this mid-term thesis, the near-term story seems clouded by ongoing legacy pressures, a slower than hoped ramp up in Aviation revenues and rising GX/aviation investment needs. As a result, our 2017E EBITDA estimate is now 8%1 below consensus and our 2018 revenue forecast sits modestly below guidance. These overhangs lead us to move to Neutral; however, we argue that once expectations rebase, investors may once again be drawn to Inmarsat’s (still) enviable growth story, and its now de-rated valuation.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Positively, late 2016 saw Inmarsat sign three major Maritime reseller agreements (Marlink, Speedcast, Navarino) and win several Aviation deals (Air New Zealand, IAG, Lufthansa, Austrian Airlines). However ongoing legacy pressures, twinned with the slow initial financial contribution of the above contracts lead us to forecast +4% 2017E revenue growth vs. Bloomberg consensus +8%. Moreover, with GX and Aviation investment costs likely to ramp ahead of revenues, we model ex-Ligado EBITDA -7% y/y (consensus +1%).

BE11:44am

So ... Caz forecasts Inmarsat to "modestly" miss 2018 targets .....

BE11:44am

... meaning dividend uncovered to 2021 and leverage of more than 3x.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

There's also a nearly identical note from Morgan Stanley.

BE11:45am

...... which follows a nearly identical one from Citigroup earlier in the week.

BE11:46am

Odd when that happens. Some kind of spontaneous realisation, I guess.

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Rather than someone talking the market down

BE11:47am

Cripes, no! I mean, Inmarsat has numbers due in March and is just entering its closed period! Why on earth would anyone be damping expectations?

BE11:47am

Here's MOST.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Estimates lowered: We reduce 2017 revenue estimates by 3% and EBITDA by 9%.
This reflects ongoing pressure in: (1) Enterprise: Lower pricing and excess capacity is causing a prolonged decline. As such, the fall in legacy revenues, such as BGAN (particularly in the oil & gas segment) and fixed to mobile are not being offset by growing M2M revenues, (2) Maritime: The tough shipping environment is impacting Inmarsat's Fleetbroadband product and declining legacy revenues remains a drag. (3) Aviation: Higher start up costs mean that we now expect aviation EBITDA to be down YoY before recovering in 2018 onwards.
On the positive side, we note: (1) Stronger outlook in Government following recent agreements with Boeing and the Navy - we estimate to be worth an incremental $40mn pa in revenues for 2017. (2) Sterling tailwind, as around 25% of the cost base is in GBP, but the company reports in USD - incremental $30mn pa benefit. (3) Release of deferred Ligado revenues from the Balance Sheet to the P&L, which is worth c$10-15mn pa, but is low margin.

undefined

Is there anything positive we can look at?

BE11:50am

Despite the small beat on LFL in 3Q, the company expects FY17 PBT to be in line with current market forecasts of £445m. We understand this is mainly driven by a reduction in the currency benefits. In fact, the company expects the weaker sterling to contribute towards £115m in PBT using a 1.23 $£ spot rate down from a £125m benefit at the time of 1H results in November using a 1.22 $£..

11:51 am
BE11:51am

The read-across for soft luxury is positive. We believe the market is ready for a strong earnings season in the luxury space following the sharp rerating of our coverage relative to the market. Bearing in mind that sales growth at Burberry underperformed peers in the last few quarters, +4% organic retail sales in 3Q bodes particularly well for LVMH Fashion & Leather Goods and Kering Luxury due to report 26 Jan and 10 Feb respectively.

PM11:56am

David Bond

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Do they explain why Fallon's still employed?

PM11:56am

Despite admitting he had not foreseen declines in college enrolment
and the knock on impact that would have on revenues in the US, Mr
Fallon insisted he would not quit as chief executive.

He said: "I absolutely acknowledge we got two big calls [on college
enrolment] wrong. We didn't see that coming.

"I am accountable and I fully accept that accountability. I am also
accountable for leading the company through a far more difficult
period than anyone could have imagined. We have to move decisively and
urgently."

Mr Fallon also revealed he would be meeting with shareholders in the
next few days.

PM11:57am

He's been decisive and urgent for a while now

11:58 am
BE11:58am

If he had seen it coming -- by glancing at college enrollment figures perhaps, or checking any of the trading updates from his peers over the past several years -- his action might not have to be quite so decisive and urgent.

BE11:58am

Still, nice to know he's on it now.
